item.name: Emacs Pinky Syndrome (EPS) chorded keyboard, version 3
Emacs Pinky Syndrome (EPS) main keymap
item.appendix: The EPS keymap reconfigures uses a small set of keys and chords using those keys to
implement all normal US ASCII characters and common editing keys to minimize usage of
the pinky fingers and thumbs, make proper wrist angle natural, reduce awkward finger
movements. If keyboard use has been crippling your hands, this may be useful to you.
The mappings are statistically organized based on standard English, and makes liberal
use of chords to implement common English words.
The "home row" for this mapping is WEF and JIO for the left and right hands. Note that
this is rotated from conventional mappings to move the wrists into an approximately
straight alignment, optimal to avoid Carpal Tunnel Syndrome, and that the pinky has no
key (they are not generally used). The left index finger is also expected to cover R, T,
G, C, V, and B, and the right index finger is expected to cover Y, U, H, N, and M. In
addition, S, D, K, and L are used by the middle and ring fingers
The keys F, E, W, C, and V are used as the left hand chord modifiers (extra1-5); J, I, O,
M, and N are the right hand versions of the same modifiers. These keys are used alone
to provide the most common characters:
W=n E=t F=space C=o V=r and N=h M=s J=e I=a O=i
Sequences of these keys, left before right or right before left, make an additional 25
inputs, including most of the rest of the alphabet and some common words and pieces of
words. Holding down E and pressing O, noted as E-O, generates "the". The reverse, O-E
generates "it". Reverses are often related though; C-O=g and O-C=gh; W-O=of and O-W=if;
V-N=and and N-V=but. Prefixing some word combos with a control changes them: ^W-O=off
When pairs of keys are pressed with one hand, e.g. EF, and a key, e.g. J, is pressed
less common characters and sequences are generated, i.e., EF-J=x and EF-M=k; the
reverse is also often related, e.g., J-EF=ex and M-EF=ck. Pairs of pairs, e.g.,
IJ-WF=though and WF-IJ=through generate larger common words and some programming
constructs. For complete details, see the spreadsheet
https://pqrs.org/osx/karabiner/contrib/eps_keymap3.ods
